"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

author.bio: Confessional Lutheran, Southern nationalist, Anglophile, historian

body:
First of all, the author of the article is a dishonest shit - they completely made up the bit about Jael having sex with Sisera (then screwed up the means of killing; she didn't bludgeon him, she drove a tent peg through his head). Such an egregious and unnecessary fabrication tells me that the author has an evil and subversive agenda. 

Second, St. Luke was a Greek, which makes the claim that more Jewishness means it's more original a bit ridiculous. 

Third, there is absolutely no evidence of tampering or editing; our New Testament manuscripts are the best-attested ancient documents in existence, and they're astonishingly consistent with each other. Delusions of a Roman Catholic conspiracy are absurd; in insisting on this alleged tampering, you're simultaneously implicating the Coptics, Eastern and Ethiopian Orthodox, and pre-Roman Catholic hegemony churches in England and Ireland. Then there's the fact that we can dang near reconstruct the whole thing from early Christians *quoting it.*

We have *mountains* of evidence that the New Testament is astonishingly well preserved. This is an interesting deviation that doesn't seem to contradict canon, but my goodness, trying to make it into proof of large-scale editing is absolutely ridiculous.

body:
It doesn't make sense that Catholic scribes would change it to say something that goes *against* their theology. More likely that the texts we have now were redacted a few times and some of the earlier editions still existed in the 5th century, which Bezae derives from. And yes, the church did edit the texts very early on, and there is plenty of evidence for it. See for yourself, even in the church's "uniform" text there are thousands of meaningful variants. And the further back you go, the more erratic they get. Unfortunately, our only majorly extant manuscripts date to the mid 2nd century at the absolute earliest, plenty of time for the church fathers to have produced their redactions and destroy all deviant manuscripts.

> Second, St. Luke was a Greek, which makes the claim that more Jewishness means it's more original a bit ridiculous.

It is actually unclear whether Luke was Jewish or gentile. He is merely mentioned as some kind of friend or acquaintance in the authentic Pauline epistles, and not much else is known about him. But the earliest converts *were* Jewish by majority, so it would make sense that the oldest texts would be more Jewish.
